div.p: ¶ The Boke of Demaundes of the ſcyence of Phyloſophye, and Aſtronomye, Betwene kynge Boctus, and the Phyloſopher Sydracke.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, howe was the worlde made, and howe holdeth it. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
GOD made Heauen and water, & when he wolde make man, after that the euyll Aungelles fell downe from heuen in abyſme. He ſayd that the world be made, and anone forthwith was his cōmaundement done. And the worlde was fo •
med vpon the water as his pleaſu •• was. And all the water that is in thayre it abydeth vpon the erthe, for 〈◊〉 can not be ſo depe nor ſo parfound • but it muſt nedes abyde on the ert • and as ye ſhall vnderſtande that th • ſame erth, and alſo this that is dyſcouered hath other water vnder hym alſo, that ſuſtayneth it. For the foundement of the erthe is the water, and the foundement of the water is the fyrmamēt, and the one and the other
hangeth and holdeth togyther by the fyrmamente, and by the myghte and wyll of God. GOD of his great myght made the worlde to the ſemblaunce of an egge, as in lykenes the ſhell of the Egge is the fyrmament, that enuyrons and goeth all aboute the world, and the whyte of the egge is the water that is betwene the fyrmament that enuyrons and goeth aboute the erth. The yelke of the egge • s the erth that enuyroneth all abou
• e with water, and ſet vpon the wa
• er. In lykewyſe as the yelke of the • gge that is ſet and enuyroned all a
• oute wt the whyte of the egge. The • eede that is betwene the yelke and he whyte of the egge, that be the folkes that be on earth, euen as the ſede is on the yelke &, thus is the forme of ye world. But then it is as rounde as a Bowle, that hath neyther heade nor tayle.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, mounteth the ſonne more vpwarde then he deſcendeth or deſcendeth he more then he mounteth. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p: THe ſonne by the morowe when he ryſeth red and clere he mounteth alway tyll halfe the day be paſt, that is called mydday. And then after the halfe day, he deſcendeth and cōmeth lower, tyll he go downe, and as red ye may ſe the ſonne at his goynge downe, as at his ryſynge, and as moche he deſcendeth downwarde as he mounteth vpwarde.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, the ſonne doth he mounte & deſcende as wel by nyght as by day. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
WHen the Sonne appereth to vs, heare, that he goeth downe and fayleth vs, he ſheweth to other folke
in another countree, that be in the other parte of the worlde, and he ſheweth hym in his turnynge to them, that the day aprocheth to as he doth vs, when the daye cōmeth and lyghteth vs. And at after mydnyght, tyll it be day he goeth lower to them, toward vs waxeth hygher, for to them he aprocheth in the nyght, and to vs in the day, & when he fayleth vs he appereth vnto them ī another countre.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, why groweth the Moone, and at ſomtyme waxeth leſſe and leſſe. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
THe Moone appeareth & ſemeth to vs that ſhe groweth, and other whyle waxeth leſſe, and all this appereth to vs, for the ſonne and the tornyng of the fyrmament, for al the whyle that ſhe is agaynſt the ſonne, ſhe is couered, and appereth vnto vs
that ſhe waxeth leſſe. And whā it appereth to vs that ſhe is al fayled and ſheweth nothyng, than ſhe is approched nyghe to the Sonne, and leſeth all her lyght, for the coueryng of the ſonne. And at the ſame poyncte that ſhe fautes all her lyght to vs, at the ſame poyncte the ſon̄e paſſeth her, for the mouement of the tyrmamente, & then ſhe dyſcouereth on the other parte of the ſonne, and then ſhe is newe ſemynge to vs here, and for the feble ſyght that we haue, we maye not ſe her at that poyncte. And euerye .xv. dayes ſhe groweth, & other .xv. dayes ſhe waneth and waxeth leſſe.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, what is the reaſon that in ſome place in the worlde, the Clyps of the Sonne and of the Moone maye be ſene, and in ſome place it maye not be ſene. Sydracke Anſwereth.
div.p:
THe Sonne maketh his Clyps, aſwell by day as by nyght, and by nyght as by daye, for when we haue day here, other folkes haue in other places nyght, and when it is nyght here with vs, it is day wt them for the fyrmament neuer ceaſeth turnynge, and therin a bydeth the ſonne the Moone, and the ſtarres, that enuyron and go aboute all the worlde, and at no tyme they fayle not theyr lyght, for whē theyr lyght fayleth to vs here, they ſhewe it to other folkes in other places, and when it fayleth other folkes there, it ſheweth to vs here. And al this is for the roundnes of the world, for the world is all roū de as an balle, for when the Sonne draweth lowe, he gyueth his lyghte to that parte yt he draweth lowe to, and then it is derke behynde hym, as and a man helde a candell lyght before hym the vyſage of hym ſhuld haue
the ſhadow. And ſo in lykewyſe doth the ſonne aboute the fyrmament, by cauſe of the roundnes of the worlde. This is the daye and the nyght, for God made the nyghte for the reſte of man, and for other creatures. And therfore when the Sonne is in the clyps here with vs, we haue it by day and therfore we may ſe it, and then it is nyght with other folkes, and therfore they maye not ſe it, for the ſhadowe of the erth Alſo when the ſōne is in the clyps wt other folkes they haue daye, and we haue nyght, therfore they may ſe it, and we may not ſe it, for the ſhadowe of the earth. And lykewyſe is the Moone as the Sōne in the clyps, when tyme and ſeaſon is, aſwell by daye as by nyght. And therfore it is day with vs when it is nyght with other folkes. Howe be it that the fyrmament maketh alway his turne for our day and our nyght
is all one, for where ſoeuer they turne they haue alway lyght & reſplendour and brightnes that God of his grace hath gyuen them.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, is there any poyncte in the daye that is good. Sydracke Anſwereth.
div.p: AT that poynct that the Moone maketh her turne at, the .xxxvi. poynctes after, thou ſhalte haue a good poyncte: & from the poyncte at .C. lvij. poynctes, another. And from that at .CCC. lxxvij. poynctes, thou ſhalte haue another. And from that poyncte at .v. M. ij. poynctes yu ſhalt haue another. And from the poyncte at .vij. C. xi. poynctes thou ſhalt haue another. And from the poynct at .CCC. xvi. poynctes thou ſhalte haue another. That is to ſay, poynctes in euery Moone where the .xxiiij. houres of the day and of the nyght ben.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, howe ſhulde a man knowe the euyll poyncte. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p: AT euery tyme that the moone is newe, thou ſhalt tell by .xvij. tymes .xvij. poynctes, and at euery tyme of the .xvij. poynctes, or as many houres as the Moone is newe ī that day that poynctes after, and the ſecond, the thyrd, the fourth, & the fyft be euyll, & then ye ſhall counte yet aſmany poynctes as ye haue tolde and counted before .v. poynctes after ben euyll poynctes. And alway to counte this counte, the houres begyn, whar the Sonne goeth downe, and the nyght and the daye be .xxiiij. houres. And they begyn at the ſōne goyng downe bycauſe the nyght was before the daye.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, is there any other folkes vnderneth vs that ſe the lyght of the Fyrmamente as we do. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
FOr bycauſe of the roundnes of the worlde there are folkes vnderneth vs that ſeeth the lyght of the fyrmament as we do, and alſo theyr fete go agaynſt our fete, and that is for the hyghenes and longnes of the parties of the world and for his roſ •
denes, for the Eeſt parte is moch hyer where the Sonne ryſeth, then the weſt parte where the Sonne goeth downe. When the ſonne ryſeth in the Eeſt, then it is dawnynge of the day in the weſt. And alſo when the ſonne goeth lowe in the weſt, thē it is euyn nyght in the Eeſt, for the greatnes & roundnes of the world, for whyle the ſōne ſhall make one ſhadowe on erth of .iiij. then ſhall the fyrmament haue
courſe in his towre .M. legues. It is not to be vnderſtand that the ſōne ſheweth not nor cōmeth not ſo lowe as the erth, nor nye to it, but a great tyme and a great way from the erth aſmoche as the length of the erth is from the one heade to the other, and aſmoch agayne, and is more ferther for to go vp, then for to go downe.

There is a lande an folkes dwellyng therin, that the Sonne abydeth not there but one houre of the day, and a none it is nyghte. There is another lande where it is darke alway as it were nyght. And whan it is in one place of world wynter, in another place it is ſōmer. And whan it is ſōmer there, it is in the other partes wynter and all this is by the reaſon of the Sonne that taketh another way, by the volent and wyll of God euery yeare.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, how longe, how large, and howe thycke is the world. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p: FOrſoth the worlde is as moch of length, as of largeneſſe, and of thyckenes the ſame, for it is all as rounde as an apple. And who wolde go, from one heed to the other ryght through the worlde, and went euerye day well and cōmonly, from the morow tyll euen, and the brede of the ſee that is betwene Eeſt and weſt, were all ferme lande and erth, and all the world were as playne as the paume of a mānes hande, no man might go from the one heed to thother, in leſſe • hen a .M. dayes, and the largeneſſe, and thyckenes is as moche.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, maye any man go aboute the worlde. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
THere is no man that may go or turne aboute the worlde, and a man myght lyue a .M. yere and more, and all the earth were ferme & playne, and yf he wolde go he ſhulde fynde ſo many countres, hylles, moū taynes, and dales. That he myghte not paſſe them in no wyſe, and alſo he ſhuld fynde ſo moch drought and drye places, that he ſhulde not fynde one ſope of water. And alſo he ſhulde fynde many peryllous and dyuers beaſtes, and foules, that he ſhulde be ſlayne and deuoured, and yf he might paſſe all theſe perylles, yet he ſhulde fynde ſo great deſerte, where there is great obſcure and darkenes that he ſhulde ſe no ſyghte. And yf he ſhulde paſſe all this, yet he ſhulde fynde ſo great & meruaylous chynes & caues in the erth, by the which the ſee that is called the ſee Betee, that paſſeth thoroughe the lande, and partes one
countre from another, and by many reaſons he might not go it. And yf it were ſo that a fowle ſhuld flye, yet he myght not do it, for the great thurſt and hunger that he ſhuld haue, for he ſhulde fynde no fode, and alſo for the great wyldernes, & for other fowles that wolde ſlee and deuour hym, and for many other reaſons.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, how many landes is there. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
THere is but one lande, but for the reaſon of the See that entreth throwout it, and partꝭ it in .iii. partyes, therof there are named .iii. Countres, withouten Iles in the ſee, but all is one lande ferme, and all be vpon one foundement, and all GOD formed and made in one houre, and all at ones. And a man were all beneth vnder the worlde, whiche were
vnpoſſyble for any man to be there, but by the wyll of God he myght wel be, and went all aboute and behelde well, he ſhulde fynde that all the erth and lande were one as well there as the ſee is not, as there as ſhe is, for ſo perfounde and depe maye no man be vnder her, but that ſame earthe, hath yet other water vnder her, that ſuſtayneth her.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, myghte a man ſayle ſo longe in a ſhyp, and he had wynde and wether at his wyll, or the ſee, that he myght come nyghe to the place where the fyrmament turneth aboute. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
AND a man were in a ſhyp, and the ſee bare hym, and the wynde put hym forth alway forwarde, and ſayled .x. yere on the ſee or more, and that Shyp parted from the Eaſt, ſhe
ſhuld be a great whyle after that, or ſhe came into the weſt, and alſo and ſhe departed from the weſt ſhe ſhuld be as longe or ſhe aryued in the Eaſt And alſo in lykewyſe in the trauerſe and ouerthwart the world, and yf it ſo were that it ware the wyl of God that a mā were as great and as bolde and hardy as all the worlde, and he were nyghe vnto the fyrmament, where he turneth about by. M M legues or more, the feere that he ſhuld haue when the fyrmament maketh his turne, and of the tempeſt & noyſe that he maketh and of his mouynge that great and bolde hardy man, as all the world ſhuld be deed anone at that ſame houre, and ſhuld not lyue one houre, nor myght not, howe be it that a man were as hardye and as great as is aforeſayd, and yet the firmament ſeaſeth not alway to turne by the wyll of God.

div.head: ¶ The kynge aſked, ſhall all the erth be enhabyted with folkes. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p: AL the earth ſhall be enhabyted, and ſhalbe deuyded in .iij. parties. The fyrſt partye is named Aſye Le Grande, and is as great as the other two. And this partye dureth from Septentrion by Orient tyl myddye. The ſeconde partye is named Ewrope and dureth from Occydent vnto neptentrion. The thirde parti is named Auffryke that dureth from myddy vnto Occydent.

div.head: ¶ The kynge aſked in what place is paradyſe Terreſtre. Sydracke Anſwereth.
div.p:
PAradyſe terreſtre is in the fyrſt region of Aſye le grande towar Orient, and there is none erthly man
that may come there but god or his Aūgels lede hym and guyde hym thy ther For this Paradyſe ſythen that Adam was eaſt and dryuen out therof by an Aungell, anone forthwith it was enuironed al aboute with great fyre that dureth frō the erth vnto the ſkie aboue that no mā may enter nor come therto. And alſo there is all aboute Paradyſe great wylderneſſes where there is great multytude of many dyuers and peryllous beaſtes.

div.head: ¶ The kynge aſked, in what place is hell. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p: HEll is in the myddes of Auffryke vnder the erth and is ſet in the myddes of earth, as a karnell of an apple is in the myddes of the apple, for as moche erth is there aboue as beneth. And there be the ſoules, that be dampned in great payne and turment without ende.

div.head: ¶ The kynge aſked, may there come any tokens or Sygnes, that a man may ſe boldely out of heauen or hell. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p: A Man may ſe opēly the waters that commeth from Paradyſe Terreſtre, for there is a well ſprynge of the which .iij. Ryuers cōmeth out of it. And one of thoſe .iij. Ryuers goeth by the parties of myddy toward Orient, and falleth into the ſee of Occydent, and that aryſeth oute of hell agayne yt is in the parties of Ynde. And the other two Ryuers, aryſeth agayne in Ewrope of an hyll there, & there paſſe by many coūtres, tyll they mete, and then they fall into the ſee, as nature requyreth. And alſo a mā may ſe in Auffryke openly .ij. hylles, that be ſoupyrall of hell, & they ceaſe not nether day nor night and be euer brennynge with fyerſe fyre.

div.head: ¶ The Kynge aſked, what is the can ſe that the blode of a man, the braynes, the mary, and the waters groweth and waxeth leſſe and more. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p: WHan God made the fyrmament the .vij. Planettes, and the .xij. Sygnes, and ſtablyſhed and ordayned them for to lyght the world, thā he ſtablyſſhed & ordayned, as a lorde that the blode, and the braynes, and the mary of mankynde, and the waters alſo ſhuld waxe and wane as the Moone doth, that is more nere the erth then any of the other planettes And alſo ſhe groweth and waneth in heauen, but to vs here on erth it ſemeth & appereth to vs that ſhe groweth & waneth here. And all this is by cauſe of the mouement of the fyrmamēt, & for the turne that ſhe maketh, for ſhe goeth all aboute the worlde.

div.head: ¶ The kynge aſked, is any man the worſe yf he be pore, or ſonne to a pore man, or bonde to another, or not ſo well fauoured as another. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
AS ſpiritually and againſt god a man is neuer the better, nor neuer the worſe for his riches, nor for his pouerte, nor for his euyll fauour, but for his workes and dedes if thou be ryche and puyſſaunt, and I poore, yet with all my pouerte, God hathe gyuen me forme of man, as he hath done to the, for as well am I borne of a woman and gotten of a man as thou arte. And alſo I haue a ſpryte as thou haſte. And I haue alſo my poore body all hole, and complet and my argumentes as thou haſt in thy ryche body. And when thou ſhalte departe & go to another worlde, yu ſh • lt go as poorely as I. And for thy ryches
nothynge may not be the better but onely by thy good dedes and workes. And thoughe I be bonde, or ſon̄e to a bonde man, I am neuer the worſe ſo that I lyue Godly and truly and clenly after the cours and nature of man. Such is the world, for ſome be riche and ſome be poore, and ſome be fayre and ſome fowle. And at theyr ende they be all one of byrthe, of lyfe, and of death, and of all other thyngꝭ of the body. And not one better than another to God warde, but onely by theyr good workes and dedes. And he that beleueth otherwyſe, beleueth folyouſlye.

div.head: ¶ The kynge aſked, whiche is the moſte delectable place in the worlde. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
THe moſte delectable place in the worlde, is there as the herte of
man loueth, and hath wyll to be, for and a man were in the fayreſt place of the worlde, and had all that euer myghte be neceſſarye and nedefull to hym, and he loued another place better, that fayre place ſhulde lyke hym nought, agaynſt the loue that he had into another place, howe be it that it were ryght fowle. And yf a mā were in the moſt vyleſt & fowleſt place that is, and he loued well that place, yet he wold thynke that it were the moſt d •
lectable place in the worlde, bycauſe that he loued it, and therfore we may ſay that the moſt delectable place it the world is there as the hert loueth and deſyreth, be it fayre or fowle.

div.head: ¶ The kyng aſked, whē all this worde was all water, was their in ye water any fyſſhe. Sydracke Anſwereth
div.p:
NAy forſoth, for when God mad other creatures he made all fyſhes,
for in the water there was no creature mouable, nor other creatures nor none other thinges but great Tenebres and derkenes, and in that water was the holy ghoſt, as a great lyght. And wyt yewel without doute that no Aungel nor Archaungell nor no creatur that euer was, nor is, nor ſhalbe, coulde not frō that tyme forwarde knowe all the puyſſaunce and the myght of God our creatoure.

div.head: ¶ The kynge aſked, whether is more the grauel of the erth, or the droppes of water of the ſee. Sydracke, An.
div.p:
THe Grauell of the erth is moch more thā be the droppes of the water of the ſee. For one handefull of Grauell, mounteth a great quantyte of droppes of water. For the verye ſmall Sande and Grauell is moche ſmaller then the droppes of water.
And the water may not be in no parte, but ſhe be vpon the erth and vpon the Grauell, and the Grauell ſuſtayneth the water and bereth it. And in many places in the world, Grauell is ryght great and ryght harde in many partes of the worlde that a man ſhall fynde no drop of water, and in the depeſt of the ſee, it can not be ſo depe but that there is Grauel & erth vnder the moſte depeſt. And therfore there is for one drop of water a .C. of Grauell. For all the water in ye world reſteth vpon erth and vpon Grauell, and often tymes when a man taketh away the erth he fyndeth water, the hard Rocke, and that Rocke ſtandeth vpon Grauell. And for this reaſon, & for the ſmalnes of the Grauell, and for the moſt parte where there is moche Grauell, there is no drop of water. Therfore the Grauell is moche more thē the droppes of water in the
ſee. But ye ſhall vnderſtande that we ſpeke not of the water, yt ſuſtayneth and bereth all the erth in the worlde.

div.head: ¶ The kyng aſked myght a man nō bre the droppes of the water of the ſee or the Grauell of the earth. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
AND the worlde were greater thē it is a .M. tymes, and a .M and were all ferme erth, and that it dured a .M. tymes a .M. yere goyng and were all enhabyted with folkes, the day and the nyght he .xxiiij. houres, and euerye houre is a .M. lxxx. poynctes, and in euery poyncte were borne a .M. M. tymes men, & as many women, and they were all full of heer, and for euery heer ſhulde haue a .M. M. tymes droppes. of water of the ſee. Yet the droppes of the ſee water. And yet the myſerycorde and the
mercye of God is more then the one and the other, or all other thynges yt be in yt world or were or ſhalbe vnto them that ſeke to haue it & deſerue it.

div.head: ¶ The kyng aſked, whiche of the .vij. planettes gouerned the world before the tyme of Noes flodde. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
BEfore the tyme of Noes flodde there were .ij. Planettes that gouerned the world. And tho were Saturnus & Iupiter: and Mars began to gouerne yt world before that flod .CC. xliiij. yere, for fro the begynnyng of Adam to the tyme of Noe it was ij. M. cc. xliiij. yere. And the .ij. M. yere gouerned Saturus and Iupiter, eueryche of them a .M. yere. And Mars began to gouerne the worlde before the flod of Noe .CC. xliiij. yere. And after Noes flod. Mars gouerned ty •
his .M. yere were ended, yt is to wyt, he gouerned after the fled .vii. C. lvi. yere. And nowe in out tyme Soll gouerneth the world, & thus ſhall ende all the other Planettes, for eueryche of thē ſhall gouerne the world a .M. yere by the wyll and cōmaundement of God. And when theſe .vij. M. yere be paſſed and and gone, from thenſe forth the world ſhall dure at the wyl, pleaſure & cōmaūdement, of almyghty God, for ferther I cannot ſay.

div.head: ¶ The kyng aſked, of the goodnes & harme that cōmeth of wyne. Sydracke, Anſwereth.
div.p:
NOble Kynge Alexandre, forget not to take tarte ſyropes in the mornyng faſtynge whan flumatyke humours abounde to moch. For it is profytable and waſteth them moche alſo I meruayle that any man may
dye or be ſycke yt eateth brede of clene and good wheete, holſome and good fleſſhe, and drynke good wyne of grapes temperatly. And yf he kepe hym fro to moch drynkyng, eatyng, & trauayle. Yf ſyckenes ouercome ſuche a man he muſt be healed as a dronken man. That is to wit he muſt be waſſhed with warme water and than ſet ouer a rennyng water betwne .ij. grene wylowes, and his ſtomacke anoynted wt an oyntment of ſandres, or ſā dalles, & haue a fumygacion of frankenſence, and other ſwete ſpices, and it wyll do him moch good: and if any man wyll forſake holy the drynkyng of wyne ought not to leue in ſodeynly at ones but lytell & ly ••• , and to mengle it euery day wt water more & more, tyll at laſt there de nothing but clere water: & ſo he may kepe his helth and good cōplection. Th ••• gouerne thy body yf thou wylt lyue longe, and
kepe my doctrynes, & conſydre theſe thynges folowyng wherin nature cō forteth greatly. That is to wyt goodly paſtymes, ſyght of great richeſſes great reuerence, victory ouer enemyes, fedynge on good meates, noyſe of mynſtralſy, ſyght of precious garmē tes, often herynge of good tydynges ſpeche of wyſe men, to enquere of thinges paſt and to come, and cōmunycacion with fayre gentylwomen.
¶ Imprinted by me Robert Wyer, dwellynge in the Duke of Suffolkes Rentes, beſyde chatynge Croſſe.
